text: Good morning, everyone.

Welcome to this episode
of This is My Architecture.

My name is Marc
and today I'm with Pierre,
from the Klap.

- Welcome, Pierre.
- Hello Marc.

Well, tell me Pierre,
could you tell us a little bit
about Klap's use case today?
Yes, so Klap does automated editing
and video processing for sports.
It is used for sports betting
or sport events of all kinds.
We manage large video streams,
for example, football matches,
we make edits, in which we include
all the goals of the football match

or statistics, such as the number
of passes per player.
Right, and today you've created
your app solution directly on AWS.
Could you tell us more about it?
Yes, we used AWS and its cloud,
first for its storage, Amazon S3,
which allows us to manage huge videos
since we handle very high quality streams,
from 50 Mbps per second,

which is about 50 gigabytes
for two hours of video.

Thus, we quickly have a lot
of video to manage
and managing that in the AWS cloud

allows us not to manage videos
on hard drives,
which creates reliability issues.
And in the same way, we also use a lot
of AWS Lambda for computations,
which also allows us

not to have a single server
doing computations,

but to distribute computations
in the Amazon Cloud.
All right, and could you describe
the architecture we have on the board?

Yes, then I'll show you
the path used by a video
in the Klap cloud.
The video arrives in an Amazon S3 bucket

and the arrival of this video
will automatically start
the execution, a Step Function execution.

This Step Function execution
will trigger sequentially
four steps.
We start first with a Lambda
that will take this video
and transform it into thousands of frames
that will be stored again on Amazon S3
as PNG.
All right, so once you've generated

all these frames, what are
you going to do with them?
Then these images are then analyzed
by a second Lambda.

But this second Lambda is going
to list the images,

and since there's a large
number of images,
there are a large amount of computations to do,

in fact, instead of doing
the computation directly,
it's going to run a batch process,
in batches of 50 to 200 images in Lambda's
that are going to be run in parallel.
So, in practice, it's going to launch,
it can be 50 or 100 Lambda's in parallel,
or up to 1000 Lambda's,

since that's what we can do
with AWS,
which will process

all the images of the video
at the same time

and will extract, thanks
to a TensorFlow model,

for example the position
of the ball in each image
and store this position again
in an Amazon S3 bucket.

All right, so you have trained
a TensorFlow model

and then imported it
into a Lambda function.
Why did you choose the Lambda inference?

Lambda has a lot
of advantages in this case.

First of all, it is a system
that is extremely reliable
because as our computation is distributed,
if one of the computation units falls,
we can restart it dynamically.

Secondly, it's extremely scalable,
as I explained,
regardless of the amount of video
we have to process.

You can constantly adjust the available
computing capacity by simply
sending more Lambda's in parallel.
And finally, in terms of cost,

it's interesting because it allows
us to manage
all our Lambda computations

and not have to pay for the scale up
and scale down

that we can have
on the usual instances.
All right, so on this second step,
you're going to generate features
that will be stored on S3.

What are you going to do
with these features afterwards?

These features are processed
by the following Lambda
in the Step Function execution.

This Lambda is similar
to a decision engine,

i.e. we know where the ball
is in each frame.

What we're going to do...
we also know where the goal is.
We just have to look at
when the ball enters the goal,

in which frame, and decide
at that moment
which editing we want to do.

In this case, we want
a slow motion of the goal.
So, that decision is made
in that Lambda,

based on all the detections
that were made in the frames,
and that will then allow us to edit.
All right, so once you've determined
the decision engine, how do you launch
the editing step?
Well, the editing step is not done
in a Lambda function.
It's done in an ECS cluster.
This ECS cluster carries EC2 instances.
These EC2 instances will carry

an FFmpeg engine that will do
the actual editing of the video
and then send this video
to the streaming platforms...
All right.

...so that it can be viewed
by the customers of our customers.

All right, and why did you
choose specifically
ECS and not Lambda for this last step?
Well, at Klap, we're big fans of Lambda.

It's got a lot of advantages
over the whole computation.

But the problem
with this last function step
is that you can't have

a computation that lasts
less than 15 minutes.

Letâ€™s imagine that we want
to edit a goal.
For the 20 minutes before that goal,
you have to do all the transcoding, etc.
These are rather heavy computations

and therefore the limitations
that are inherent

to Lambda functions,
in fact, can create

business problems for us,
on this last step.
So we preferred to use an ECS Cluster,
which allows us to have fewer limitations,
to be freer.
And since it's not
the most expensive step for us,
we didn't need
to optimize a lot in this part.
This part, all right.
And could you share some figures
on the use of this architecture today?
So, this architecture today allows us

to process 1 to 5 million
analyzed images per day

for costs that will be less than
10,000 euros per day.
It may seem expensive,
but video is extremely heavy to process.
The computations are heavy.
And compared to other solutions,
our analysis is very competitive.
The other advantage we have is that,

regardless of the amount of data
we're going to have as input,

we can guarantee processing
at least up to this step,
on this first part,
which will last less than five minutes.
For example, to process large batches
of our users' data archives,
this is an extremely fast solution.
All right, and what improvements
could you make to this architecture?
There's a lot of improvements.
The first point that is important for us
is to reduce the 5-minute slot,

to be able to reduce it on live streams,
to be able to be able

to output a result
in less than 30 seconds.
And for that, we hope to connect...

Well, we are currently connecting
an Amazon Kinesis stream

that will replace the input
by the S3 bucket

and that will allow to have
more fluidity in the stream

and to manage the stream
really in real time.
The other point is to transform,
to complete this architecture
with GPU processing at the Lambda level,

to be able to benefit
from hybrid processing
and to be able to run larger
TensorFlow models,

which are not nowadays part
of the Lambda functions.
All right.

Thank you Pierre for sharing
your experience with us.
Thank you Marc for inviting us.

And thank you for following us
on this episode
of This is My Architecture.
Goodbye.
